Flourishing - growing or developing successfully. Languishing - becoming weak or losing strength. Diminutive - very small or tiny. Mesmerising - capturing complete attention. Temporary - lasting only for a short time.

Repulse - to drive back or cause strong dislike. Entice - to attract or tempt by offering pleasure or advantage. Allure - to attract or charm. Invite - to ask someone to come or participate. Tangle - to twist together in a confusing mass.

solution.explanation: Indifferent - having no interest or concern. Inquisitive - showing curiosity or a strong desire to learn. Uncanny - strange or mysterious, often in an unsettling way. Indeterminate - not exactly known, established, or deﬁned. Intelligent - having or showing high mental capacity.

Dashing - stylish, neat, and well-groomed. Sloppy - careless, untidy, or poorly done. Untidy - not neat or well-organized. Humid - having a high level of moisture in the air. Rough - uneven or not smooth.

Retained - kept or held onto something. Disposed - to get rid of something. Minded - inclined or having a certain attitude. Detained - held back or kept from proceeding. Pretended - acted as if something were true when it is not.

Cheerful - noticeably happy and optimistic. Miserable - extremely unhappy or uncomfortable. Melodious - having a pleasant tune; harmonious. Settled - established in a particular place or condition. Restrained - kept under control.

question: Select the most appropriate ANTONYM  of  the  underlined  word  in  the following sentence to ﬁll in the blank; Most  of  the  land  near  the  town  is  barren  , but  the  efforts  of  the  farmers  have turned it __________ . SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Fertile - capable of producing abundant vegetation or crops. Barren - unable to produce any vegetation or crops. Sterile - not able to reproduce. Infertile - not able to conceive children or young. Unfruitful - not yielding fruit or success.

question: Select  the  most  appropriate ANTONYM  of  the  word  in  the  brackets  to ﬁll in the blank; The  ______  to  the  venue  was  decorated with beautiful lights. [exit] SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Entry - a place for entering, such as a door, gate, etc. Exit - a way out, especially from a building or a large enclosed space. House - a building for human habitation. Allow - permit or give permission. Forbid - refuse to allow. Prohibit - formally forbid something by law or authority. Call - summon or request someone to come. Forsake - abandon or leave.

Direct - straight and clear in course or action. Meander - to wander aimlessly or without a clear direction. Ramble - to talk or walk aimlessly without purpose. Deputise - to act on behalf of someone in their absence. Conﬁrm - to establish the truth or correctness of something.

solution.explanation: Safeguard - to protect or defend from harm. Jeopardise - to put in danger or at risk. Risk - the possibility of loss or harm. Peril - serious and immediate danger. Jape - a joke or prank.

Resilient - able to withstand or recover quickly. Brittle - easily broken or cracked. Crunchy - making a crisp sound when bitten. Delicate - fragile or easily damaged. Aloof - emotionally distant or detached.

Attack - to take aggressive action against. Secure - to make sure something is protected from danger or threat. Succeed - to achieve a desired aim. Save - to keep safe from harm or loss. Trundle - to move or roll heavily or clumsily.

Exile - the state of being barred from one's native country. Receive - to be given or presented with something. Admit - to allow entry or access. Reward - something given in recognition of service, effort, or achievement. Fund - a sum of money saved or made available for a particular purpose.

question: Select the most appropriate ANTONYM  of  the  word  in  brackets  to  ﬁll in the blank; She  has  _______  (witty)  remarks  about everything. SSC CGL 12/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Unamusing - not entertaining. Witty - cleverly humorous or sharp in expression. Sorry - feeling regret or sorrow. Whimsical - playfully unpredictable or fanciful. Woeful - full of sorrow or misery.

Healthy - in good physical or mental condition. Paralysed - unable to move or act. Demure - modest, shy, or reserved. Stiﬂed - unable to breathe properly. Sultry - hot and humid, or passionate and alluring.

Success - the accomplishment of an aim or purpose. Catastrophe - a sudden and widespread disaster. Nurture - to care for and encourage growth or development. Immaculate - perfectly clean or free from ﬂaws. Disaster - a sudden event causing great damage or suffering.

Engrossing - absorbing all attention or interest Monotonous - lacking in variety and interest. Tiresome - causing one to feel bored or annoyed. Tedious - too long, slow, or dull. Rational - based on or in accordance with reason or logic.

Expansion - the action of becoming larger or more extensive. Epitome - a summary of a written work. Exhort - to strongly encourage or urge someone to do something. Lucid - clear and easy to understand. Precise - exact, accurate, and detailed.

solution.explanation: Certain - known for sure. Ambiguous - open to more than one interpretation. Puzzling - confusing or diﬃcult to understand. Dubious - hesitating or doubting. Vague - not clearly expressed or deﬁned.

solution.explanation: Permit - to allow or give permission. Refuse - to indicate or show unwillingness to accept. Repress - to restrain or hold back. Balk - to hesitate or be unwilling to accept an idea or undertaking. Accord - to agree or be in harmony.

Processed - treated or prepared by a series of mechanical or chemical operations for use or sale.

Enthusiastic - showing intense and eager enjoyment. Reluctant - unwilling and hesitant. Desperate - having an urgent need or desire. Obedient - complying or willing to comply with orders.

Liberal - open to new ideas. Dogmatic - stubbornly adhering to a particular set of beliefs. Concerned - worried about something. Conservative - holding traditional views. Diplomatic - skilled in dealing with sensitive matters.

Unsuccessful - not achieving the desired outcome or result. Triumphant - having won a victory or achieved success. Flourishing - growing or developing in a healthy or vigorous way. Jubilant - feeling or expressing great happiness and triumph. Tender - soft or gentle.

question: I love the [ stunning ] view of the mountain. SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Mundane - lacking interest or excitement. Stunning - extremely impressive or attractive. Toxic - harmful or poisonous. Superﬂuous - unnecessary, especially through being more than enough. Smashing - excellent or very impressive.

Facilitate - to make an action or process easier. Hinder - to create diﬃculties that result in delay or obstruction. Praise - to express approval or admiration. Joy - a feeling of great happiness. Block - to obstruct or prevent movement or progress.

Avoidable - able to be prevented or avoided. Inevitable - certain to happen. Inexorable - impossible to stop or prevent. Clear - easy to perceive or understand. Conﬁdent - feeling or showing certainty in oneself or something.

Accuse - to charge someone with wrongdoing. Absolve - to free someone from guilt or responsibility. Commend - to praise formally or oﬃcially. Excuse - to forgive someone for a fault or offense. Appeal - to make a serious or urgent request.

Depreciate - to reduce in value over time. Appreciate - to increase in value. Depict - to represent or show something through art or description. Acknowledge - to accept or admit the existence or truth of something. Esteem - to regard with respect and admiration.

Abstract - existing in thought or as an idea but not having a physical existence. Material - the substance or matter from which something is made. Cheap - low in price. Concrete - existing in a physical form. Temporary - lasting for only a limited period.

Regulate - to control or maintain something according to rules or laws. Foment - to stir up trouble or rebellion. Proximity - the state of being near in space or time. Remoteness - the state of being far away in distance or time. Separation - the act of moving or being apart from something or someone.

Incoherent - unclear or diﬃcult to understand. Intelligible - able to be understood. Scriptable - able to be written or expressed in a script or code. Embezzle - to secretly take money that belongs to an organization or business you work for. Deliberate - done consciously and intentionally.

Deplorable - shockingly bad. Laudable - deserving praise and admiration. Commendable - worthy of praise or approval. Severe - very intense or harsh in degree or manner. Humorous - causing laughter or amusement.

Appear - to become visible or come into view. Dissolve - to be absorbed by a liquid. Vanish - to disappear suddenly and completely. Fade - to gradually lose brightness or strength. Solve - to ﬁnd an answer or solution to a problem or question.

Signiﬁcant - suﬃciently great or important to be worthy of attention. Nominal - existing in name only. Nasty - very unpleasant, offensive, or harmful. Sound - in good condition. Constant - occurring continuously or repeatedly.

Loathe - to feel intense dislike or disgust for something. Forgive - to stop feeling angry or resentful towards someone for an offense. Unburden - to relieve oneself of a burden or responsibility. Requite - to return a favor or respond to a kindness. Clear - to remove or get rid of something.

question: The  pool  was  too  _________  at  this end for kids to play [SHALLOW] .SSC CGL 25/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

question: She  is  a [ veteran ] journalist  known for her powerful writing style. SSC CGL 24/07/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Novice - a person who is new or inexperienced in a particular skill or activity. Veteran - experienced person. Renowned - famous and well-known. Creviced - having a narrow crack or opening. Conditioned - trained or accustomed to a certain behavior or situation.

question: Choose  the  ANTONYM  of  the word [ 'fetish' ] in the given sentence; Shilpi  has  a  ﬁxed  indifference  and obsession towards problems in life. SSC CGL 24/07/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Indifference - a lack of interest or feeling towards somebody / something. Fetish - intense and unusual attraction or ﬁxation on a speciﬁc object or idea. Fixed - staying the same, not changing. Problems - diﬃculties or challenges. Obsession - thinking about something all the time, being too focused on it.

question: The  lizard's  light  brown  skin  acts as [ camouﬂage ] in the desert sand. SSC CGL 24/07/2023 (4th shift)

question: He  was  riding  his  bike  on  a [ bumpy ] surface. SSC CGL 25/07/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Steady- smooth and stable; without changes. Bumpy - marked by unevenness; not smooth. Jerky - characterized by sudden starts and stops; lacking smoothness. Uneven - not level or regular; having variations in height or surface. Choppy - uneven like waves.

Sensible - logical and practical. Absurd - extremely unreasonable or illogical. Tolerable - capable of suffering patiently. Adorable - extremely charming. Lovable - very easy to like or feel affection.

question: Select the most appropriate ANTONYM  of  the  underlined  word  to  ﬁll in the blank; While  most  friends [ persuaded ] him  to choose  the  career,  there  were  a  few who_____ him from doing so. SSC CGL 26/07/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Avoided - stayed away from or kept from happening. Confronted - facing a situation or problem directly. Resisted - fought against or opposed. Challenged - questioned or disputed something. Encountered - came across or met unexpectedly.

solution.explanation: Sporadic - occurring irregularly or occasionally. Incessant - continuing without interruption or pause. Insistent - ﬁrmly saying that something must be done. Daily - occurring every day. Continual - happening regularly or frequently without interruption.

solution.explanation: Midget - something that is very small Behemoth - a huge or monstrous creature. Colossus - a very large structure. Dreadnought - one that is among the largest or most powerful of its kind.

solution.explanation: Morose - unhappy or annoyed and unwilling to speak, smile. Jolly - happy and cheerful. Tabular - consisting of or presented in columns or tables. Festive - having or producing happy and enjoyable feelings suitable for a festival. Witty - using words in a clever and funny way.

question: Select  the  most  appropriate antonym  to  substitute  the  bracketed word in the given sentence; The  lens  in  this  collection  is  focused  very carefully upon the (  quotidian  ), with all of its utterly familiar vexations. SSC MTS 10/05/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Sporadic - Occurring at irregular intervals. Quotidian - occurring every day. Mandatory - required or compulsory. Obligatory - compulsory.

question: Select  the  most  appropriate antonym  to  substitute  the  bracketed word in the given sentence; She  ventured  to  go  back  to  the  tree  of  the (  tryst  ),  the  mulberry  with  the  shining white fruit. SSC MTS 19/05/2023 (Evening)

question: Select  the  most  appropriate ANTONYM  of  the  word [ ‘dwindle’ ] in  the sentence given below; Rahul  advised  Neerja  to  appreciate  or motivate  her  younger  brother  and  not  to dwindle or neglect his ideas all the time. SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: Complement - to enhance the qualities of something by adding another thing. Extraneous - of external origin and may or may not be capable of becoming an essential part Inherent - existing in something as a permanent, essential, or characteristic attribute Natural - all the animals, plants, and other things in the world which are not made or caused by humankind Induce - succeed in persuading or leading someone to do something Restricted - limited in extent, number, scope, or action

Emulate - Match or surpass a person or achievement, typically by imitation. Neglect - Refuse to take notice of or acknowledge. Respect - Treat something or someone with kindness and care. Spoilt - Diminish or destroy the value or quality of something. Bash - Strike hard and violently.

abundant Scanty - Small or insuﬃcient in quantity or amount. Abundant - Existing or available in large quantity. Expedient - Convenient and practical although possibly improper or immoral. Paltry - Less than expected or needed; too small or slight. Nasty - Very bad or unpleasant.

Civility Asperity - Harshness of tone or manner. Civility - Formal politeness in behaviour or speech. Virility - The quality of having strength, energy, and a strong sex drive. Acridity - Extreme bitterness. Curiosity - A strong desire to know or learn something.

Informal - Having a relaxed, friendly, or unoﬃcial style, manner, or nature. Slack - Not stretched or held tightly in position; loose. Slang - A type of language consisting of words and phrases that are regarded as very informal.
Scarce - not easy to ﬁnd or get. Rife - very common Ripe - ready to be picked and eaten Popular - liked by many people or by most people in a group Serene - calm and peaceful

question: Select  the  most  appropriate ANTONYM  of  the  word [ ‘Exaggerate’ ] from the given sentence. Rajni  did  understate  Sheila’s  embroider work  as,  according  to  her,  it  was worthless  to  decorate  a  piece  of  cloth with abstract ideas and then elaborate it to the audience on. the stage. SSC CHSL 06/06/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Exaggerate means to represent (something) as being larger, better, or worse than it really is. So “understate” will be the right answer. Understate means to describe or represent (something) as being smaller or less good or important than it really is.
Comic means funny. The opposite will be tragic which means something that causes distress or sorrow. Option c is the most appropriate answer.
Frivolous means not having any serious purpose or value. So option d serious is the most appropriate answer.

question: Which  word  in  the  given  sentence is the ANTONYM of [ –  susceptible ] The  president  claimed  he  was  immune from prosecution. SSC CHSL 09/06/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Susceptible means likely or liable to be inﬂuenced or harmed by a particular thing. And immune means protected and exempt. So option c immune is the most appropriate answer.

question: You  have  made  only [ perfunctory ] attempts to understand me! .SSC CHSL 09/06/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Perfunctory is used for something carried out without real interest, feeling, or effort. So option (b) careful is the antonym for perfunctory, it is the most appropriate answer.
Deﬁle means to damage the purity or appearance of something. Purify means to make something clean.So option d purify is the most appropriate answer.

Tedious is boring and tiresome. Exciting means causing great enthusiasm and eagerness. So option ‘d’ exciting is the most appropriate answer. Slack means loose. Abstract means existing in thought only as an idea. Gallant is brave.

Siege means the act of surrounding a place by an armed force in order to defeat those defending it. So option C clearance is the most appropriate answer. Deference is polite submission and request. Trance is a half conscious state. Inference is a conclusion reached on the basis of evidence and reasoning.

Raze - to completely destroy a building, town, etc. so that nothing is left Build - to make something by putting pieces, materials, etc. together Ease - a lack of diﬃculty Comfort - the state of having everything your body needs, or of having a pleasant life Ruin - to damage something so badly that it loses all its value, pleasure.

Obscure - not well known Apparent - that seems to be real or true but may not be Blurred - diﬃcult to see Cloudy - not clear Veiled - not expressed directly or clearly
Sober - not affected by alcohol Drunk - having drunk too much alcohol Straight - with no bends or curves, going in one direction only Calm - not excited, worried, or angry Unwell - sick

Altercation - a noisy argument or disagreement Agreement - the state of agreeing with somebody/something Argument - an angry discussion between two or more people who disagree with each other Quarrel - an angry argument or disagreement Controversy - public discussion and disagreement about something
Taut - stretched very tight Tight - ﬁxed ﬁrmly in position and diﬃcult to move or remove Slack - not tightly stretched Solid - hard and ﬁrm Strong - physically powerful

Proclaim- to make something known oﬃcially or publicly Conceal- to hide something/somebody Exhibit- to show something in a public place for people to enjoy or to give them information Evince- reveal the presence of something Announce - to make something known publicly and oﬃcially.

Astound - to surprise somebody very much Clarify - to make something become clear and easier to understand Confuse - to make somebody unable to think clearly or to know what to do Shock - to cause an unpleasant feeling of surprise in somebody Stun - to make a person very surprised

Alien Indigenous - people, animals or plants living or growing in the place where they are from originally Alien - a creature that comes from another planet Innate - ability or quality that you have when you are born Natural - existing in nature; not made or caused by human beings Primitive - very simple and not developed

Satisfaction Remorse - a feeling of sadness because you have done something wrong Satisfaction - the feeling of pleasure that you have when you have done, got or achieved what you wanted Empathy - the ability to imagine how another person is feeling and so understand his/her mood Regret - to feel sorry that you did something or that you did not do something Sorrow - a feeling of great sadness because something bad has happened

Release Suppress - to stop something by using force Release - to allow somebody/something to be free Abolish - to end a law or system oﬃcially Quash - to say that an oﬃcial decision is no longer true or legal Contain - to have something inside or as part of itself

honest Sly - acting or done in a secret or dishonest way Honest - telling the truth Thick - having a large distance between its opposite sides Stiff - ﬁrm and diﬃcult to bend or move

close Remote - far away from where other people live Unlikely - not likely to happen Secret - something that is not or must not be known by other people Unknown - that somebody does not know

start Cease - to stop or end Start - to begin doing something Stop - to ﬁnish moving or make something ﬁnish moving Catch - to take hold of something that is moving, usually with your hand or hands Halt - a short stop in some activity, movement or growth

slight Hefty - big and strong or heavy Slight - very small Handsome - attractive Generous - happy to give more money, help, etc. than is usual or expected Liberal - accepting different opinions or kinds of behaviour

Dull Glittering - shining brightly with many small ﬂashes of light Shiny - causing a bright effect when in the sun or in light Dull - not interesting or exciting Attractive- that pleases or interests you Stingy - unwilling to give anything especially money .

Dullness Radiance - light or heat as emitted or reﬂected by something. Dullness - the fact of not being interested or exciting Brilliance - great brightness Glow - to produce light and/or heat without smoke or ﬂames Glitter - a shiny appearance consisting of many small ﬂashes of light

Obscure Renowned - Known and admired by many people for some special quality or achievement Obscure - not well known Vain - failing to produce the result you want Noted - well known Glorious - having or deserving fame or success
Inconspicuous Prominent - important or famous Inconspicuous - not easily noticed Dangerous - likely to cause injury or damage Crazy - very silly or foolish Evident - clear to the eye or mind

Different Alike - very similar Different - not the same Ordinary - not unusual or different from others Similar - like somebody/something but not exactly the same Same - exactly like the one already mentioned

free Nab - to catch or arrest somebody who is doing something wrong Free - not in prison, in a cage, etc.; not held or controlled Catch - to take hold of something that is moving, usually with your hand or hands Grab to take something with a sudden movement Arrest - the act of arresting somebody

Unwise Farsighted - being able to see what will be necessary in the future and making plans for it Cautious - taking great care to avoid possible danger or problems Proactive - controlling a situation by making things happen rather than waiting for things to happen and then reacting to them Unwise - showing a lack of good judgement Careful - thinking about what you are doing so that you do not have an accident or make mistakes, etc. SSC CGL 2020 Tier - 1

Cowardly - in a way that is not at all brave and tries to avoid danger Stalwart - always loyal to the same organization, team, etc. Robust - strong and healthy Stout- strong and thick Firm - able to stay the same shape when pressed

Compliment - a statement or action that shows admiration for somebody Slur - an unfair comment or an insult Mixture - a combination of different things Insult - to speak or act rudely to somebody Assortment - a group of different things or of different types of the same thing; a mixture

Diminish - to become or to make something smaller or less important Augment - to increase the amount, value, size, etc. of someth ing Extend - to make something longer or larger Expand - to become or to make something bigger Spread - to affect a larger area or a bigger group of people

Cheerful - showing that you are happy Downcast - sad and without hope Disappointed - sad because you/ somebody/something did not succeed Distressed - very upset or unhappy Successful - having achieved what you wanted
Relaxed :not worried or tense Hassled - to annoy somebody Annoyed - feeling angry or slightly angry Worried - a small aircraft that can go straight up into the air Stressed - worried and nervous

Moderate - neither too much nor too little of something Lavish - pending a large amount of money Excessive - too great or extreme Grand - impressive and large or important Generous - happy to give more money, help, etc. than is usual

Rich - people with a lot of money or property Impoverished - to make somebody/ something poor or lower in quality Needy - not having enough money, food, clothes, etc. Unlucky - having or causing bad luck Deprived - not having enough of the basic things in life, such as food, money, etc.

Unite - to join together for a particular purpose Ramify - to split into branches or constituent parts Isolate - to put or keep somebody/something separate from other people or things Divide - to separate into different parts Insulate - to protect something with a material that prevents electricity, heat, or sound from passing through

Aﬃrm - to say formally or clearly that something is true or that you support something strongly Vitiate - to make something less effective. Violate - to break a rule, an agreement, etc. Annul - to state oﬃcially that something is no longer legally valid or recognized.

Hoard - to collect and store large quantities of something Fritter - waste time, money, or energy on triﬂing matters. Spoil - to change something good into something bad, unpleasant, useless, etc Spread - to affect a larger area or a bigger group of people

Oppose - to disagree with somebody’s beliefs, actions, or plans Corroborate - to support a statement, idea, etc. Validate - to show that something is true Conﬁrm - to say or show that something is true or correct, Verify - to check or state that something is true

Cowardly - in a way that is not at all brave Intrepid - without any fear of danger . Unemotional - not having or showing strong feelings Sentimental - producing or connected with emotions Responsive - paying attention to somebody/something

Pleasant - nice, enjoyable Horrendous - very bad or unpleasant Watchful - careful to notice things Dreary - not at all interesting or attractive; boring Frightening - making you feel afraid or shocked
Mild - not strong Pungent - very strong Biting - to cut or attack somebody /something with your teeth Sour - having a sharp taste like that of a lemon Sharp - very great and sudden

Reasonable - acceptable and appropriate in a particular situation Inordinate - much greater than usual or expected Exorbitant - much more expensive than it should be Irrational - not based on reason or clear thought Disproportionate - too large or too small when compared to something else

Starvation - suffering or death because there is not enough food sustenance - the food and drink that people, animals and plants need in order to live and stay healthy refreshment - light food and drinks that are available at a cinema, theatre or other public places livelihood - the way that you earn money nourishment - to provide food, drink and daily care to someone

Ordered (having elements arranged or identiﬁed according to a rule) Disheveled: very untidy/ unarranged type or disarrange Cluttered - to cover or ﬁll something with lots of objects in an untidy way Untidy - not well arranged Unkempt - not neat and orderly. Ordered will be an antonym of the given word disheveled.

Enlighten - give someone spiritual knowledge or insight. Bewilder - cause someone to become perplexed and confused. Weaken - make or become weaker in power, resolve, or physical strength. Terrify - cause to feel extreme fear. Confuse - make someone bewildered or perplexed.
Connected - to be joined to something Disjointed - not clearly connected and therefore diﬃcult to follow Abrupt - sudden and unexpected Sharp - having a very thin but strong edge or point

Distinguished - important, successful, and respected by other people Nondescript - not having any interesting or unusual qualities Ordinary - normal, not unusual or different from others Vague - not clear or deﬁnite Common- happening or found often or in many places

Inclusive - including all the services or items normally expected or required. Exclusive - not including somebody /something; without Expansive - (i) covering a wide area in terms of space or scope (ii) (used about a person) talking a lot in an interesting way; friendly. Incisive - (of a person or mental process) intelligently analytical and clear-thinking.

Faulty Infallible - (used about a person) never making mistakes or being wrong. Faulty - not working or made correctly; having defects. Unfailing - without error or fault. Dependable - trustworthy and reliable; Reliable So, Faulty is the most appropriate antonym of infallible.

Morbid Cheerful - feeling happy, showing that you are happy Morbid - showing interest in unpleasant things, for example disease and death Horrid - very unpleasant or unkind Gloomy - dark in a way that makes you feel sad Cruel - causing physical or mental pain or suffering to somebody/something

Weighted - to hold something down with a heavy object or objects Buoyant - ﬂoating or able to ﬂoat or able to keep things ﬂoating Enthusiastic - full of excitement and interest in something Lively - full of energy, interest, excitement, etc. Bouncy - full of energy, lively SSC CPO 2019 Tier- 2

Perfection - the state of being perfect or without fault. Flaw - a mistake in something that makes it not good enough, or means that it does not function as it should. Defect - something that is wrong with or missing from somebody/something. Weakness - a fault or lack of strength, especially in a person’s character.

Material - connected with real or physical things rather than the spirit or emotions. Spiritual - concerning deep thoughts, feelings or emotions rather than the body or physical things. Sacred - connected with God, a god or religion. Divine - connected with God or a god. Ethereal - extremely delicate and light, in a way that seems unreal.

Enjoyment - the action or condition of getting pleasure or satisfaction from something. Exasperation - irritation, condition of extreme annoyance. Resentment - a feeling of indignant displeasure. Pique - to arouse anger or resentment. Wrath - very great anger or intense rage.

Convene - to come together or to bring people together for a meeting, etc. Mobilize - to organize people or things to do something. Assemble - to come together or bring somebody/something together in a group.

Comfort - the feeling of being physically relaxed and in no pain. Menace - a danger or threat. Peril - something that is very dangerous. Threat - a warning that somebody may hurt, kill or punish you, if you do not do what he/she wants.

Rude - someone who is not polite. Suave - conﬁdent, elegant and polite, sometimes in a way that does not seem sincere. Polite - having good manners and showing respect for others. Charming - very pleasing or attractive. Brisk - quick or using a lot of energy.

Digniﬁed - Behaving in a calm, serious way that makes other people respect you. Ignoble - not honourable in character or purpose. Craven - contemptibly lacking in courage, cowardly. Corrupt - Doing or involving illegal or dishonest things in exchange for money, etc. Abject - terrible and without hope.

Passive - showing no reaction, feeling or interest; not active Devout - strongly or actively religious Proﬁcient - able to do a work very well, skilled. Profound - something deep in meaning, having strong insight.
Disguise - to change the appearance of something so that others cannot recognize it. Manifest - to show or perceive something clearly. Distinguish - to make something different from others.

Deﬂated - to make something smaller by letting the air or gas out of it. Bloated - swelling, pompous Arrogant - thinking that you are better and more important than others. Turgid - swollen or congested.

Provincial - .connected with one of the large areas that some countries are divided into or relating to a province. Metropolitan - relating to a large city. Agreeable- ready to agree. Heinous - utterly odious and wicked. Biased - -to inﬂuence somebody /something, especially unfairly to give an advantage to one group. Unwilling - not wanting to do something. Unhealthy - not having good health.

permit -To allow somebody to do something or to allow someone to live in a country. Deport - To force somebody to leave a country because he/she has no legal right to be there. Dishevelled - very untidy (used about a person’s appearance) Prim - formal, proper. very formal and correct in behaviour and easily shocked by anything rude: Mature - fully grown or fully developed. Principle - a rule for good behaviour, based on what a person believes is right

Inﬂexible -That cannot be changed or made more suitable for a particular situation. Insincere - pretending to feel something that you do not really feel. Truthful - Honest, truth.
